column5: I've been tying my own spinners for a July trip and was wondering what color spinner blades do most of you find work the best, I've always had the best luck with red or orange but have found out that a nickle color works well also.
If you fish stained water it's pretty tough to beat hammered brass or copper.

As a very general rule, dark water/cloudy day: Darker skirt, copper blade(s) Clearer water/sunny day: Lighter skirt, silver blade(s). As I said very general rule. You still have to consider aggressiveness of fish. If fish are more aggressive use faster presentation w/single blade. Less agreesive fish: slower presentation w/tandem blades. Usually colorado or indiana for single/faster presentation. Willow leaf for tandem /slower presentation. It's still a crap shoot though. What size blades, hammered finish, large/small tandem, willow leaf tandem, combo willow leaf/colorado or indiana tandem? A lot of it is guess work. Hope you're now as totally confused as I am when deciding what to use when fishing spinners:-) Just kidding. Hope this helps some. As an afterthought though, I have a few name brand/fairly exspensive spinners. I also have quite a few of the cheap/local variety. It seems that I catch more on the $0.99-$1.29 ones than I do the $3.00 plus models. Just some more (fish) food for thought. Anyway, Good Luck and Good Fishing! Joe

I always make my own mainly just for something to do, i will be taking a boatload of different blades along, although the ones that I really like you can only buy in Canada and usually I'm in such a hurry to get there that I don't spend the time to stop and look for them. thanks for the advice.
The ones I wouldn't leave home without in no particular order: Chartreuse, gold/hammered gold, white/pearl, florescent orange, metallic purple. Of course I haul up just about every color there is.
